epigraph: Good friendship is the whole of the spiritual path.
If you haven’t found a teacher you’re happy with, practice the guaranteed teaching.

Flung open are the doors to the deathless!
Let those with ears to hear decide their faith.
When the Realized One arises in the world, a great light appears. Darkness no longer prevails.
The noble eightfold path is right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion.
Just as the ocean has one taste, the taste of salt, this teaching has one taste, the taste of freedom.
The Realized One does as he says and says as he does.
The goal of the spiritual life is the unshakable freedom of heart.
In giving food, one gives five things: long life, beauty, happiness, strength, and clear speech.

By defilement of mind, beings are defiled; by purification of mind, beings
are purified.
When mindfulness of breathing is developed, even the final breaths in and out are known.
A family where the children honor their parents in their home is said to live with Brahmā.
A master of meditation thinks what they want to think, and don’t think what they don’t want to think.
When they have fulfilled this noble ethics, they experience a blameless happiness inside themselves.
The Buddha said to the monks who were quarrelling: “If animals can be courteous to each other, so can you.”
Mindfulness of breathing is peaceful and refined, a deliciously pleasant meditation.
When a good person is reborn into a family, it benefits their parents, their spouse and children, their servants and workers, and their friends and companions.
When you abuse, harass, and attack me, I don’t accept it. It still belongs to you.
They give up lying. They speak the truth and stick to the truth. They’re honest and trustworthy, and don’t trick the world with their words.
They reconcile those who are divided, supporting unity, delighting in harmony, loving harmony, speaking words that promote harmony.
They speak in a way that’s mellow, pleasing to the ear, lovely, going to the heart, polite, likable and agreeable to the people.
Whatever you frequently think about and ponder over becomes your heart’s inclination.
One gives up killing living creatures, renouncing the rod and the sword, scrupulous and kind, living full of compassion for all creatures.

For how can a sensible person like me
get in a fight with a fool?
That which is called ‘mind’ is always changing, like a monkey swinging through the forest.
One who sees the teaching sees me. One who sees me sees the teaching.
I do not see a single thing that, when it is developed like this, is as workable as the mind.
Here are these roots of trees, and here are these empty huts. Practice absorption! Don’t be negligent! Don’t regret it later!
Greed, hate, and delusion are unskillful.
Don’t be judgmental about people.
A lay follower should not engage in these five trades: weapons, living creatures, meat, intoxicants, and poisons.
Since a Realized One is poised in the midst of things seen, heard, thought, and known, he is the poised one.
A fool is characterized by their deeds; an astute person is characterized by their deeds. And wisdom is evident in its outcome.
If you’re not skilled in the ways of another’s mind, then be skilled in the ways of your own mind.
When the Buddha knew that their minds were ready, uplifted and gladdened, he explained the special teaching of the Buddhas.
He who would nurse me, let him nurse the sick.
Four good-hearted friends: the helper, the friend in good times and bad, the counselor, and the one who’s compassionate.
I’m so fortunate to have good friends who advise and instruct me out of kindness and compassion.
Possessions, honor, and popularity are terrible.
I shall not mollycoddle you like a potter their damp, unfired pots.
Our bodily behavior will be pure. But we won’t glorify ourselves or put others down on account of this.

A teacher should look upon his pupil as a son. A pupil should look upon his
teacher as a father.
Four ways of being inclusive: Giving, kind speech, taking care, and equality.
Four ways of being inclusive: Giving, kind speech, taking care, and equality.

The little streams are noisy,
but silent flow the great rivers.
Whatever you think it is, it turns out to be something else.
The mind is the forerunner of all things.

Anger is never soothed by anger,
it is only soothed by love.
Here you rejoice, after death you rejoice.
Diligence is the path to the deathless.
Alas, soon this body will lie discarded on the ground.
If you know you’re a fool, you’re wise at least to that extent.

What is laughter, what is joy, when the world is ever burning?
Shrouded by darkness, would you not seek a light?

For countless lives I have wandered seeking the housebuilder.
Painful is birth ever and again.

For countless lives I have wandered seeking the housebuilder.
Painful is birth ever and again.
This teaching is for those of few wishes, not those of many wishes.
All conditions are impermanent.
We will be grateful and thankful. We won’t forget the smallest thing done for us.
With a boundless heart one should love all living beings.

I’ll make sure that you, Death,
won’t even see the path I travel.

The path to extinguishment
is where my mind delights.

The unfaltering, the unshakable, that which is beyond compare:
I shall go there for sure, I have no doubt of that.
These are all terms for the noble eightfold path: ‘divine vehicle’, or else ‘vehicle of truth’, or else ‘supreme victory in battle’.

Get up and meditate!
What’s the point in sleeping?
Fear is born from embracing violence.

The sage has arrived at the truth,
the brahmin stands on the shore.

A sage doesn’t claim to be equal,
or better or worse.

Ever mindful, see the world as empty.
Then the King of Death won’t find you.

Peaceful and clear, free of worries and wishes,
they’ve gone beyond rebirth and old age.
Give up what’s not yours. Giving it up will be for your welfare and happiness.

Should a person do good,
let them do it again and again.
It’s impossible to indulge in sensual pleasures without sensual desire.

Don’t look at the faults of others or what they have or haven’t done.
Consider rather what you yourself have or haven’t done.

I’ve cut out the arrow, put down the burden, finished the task!
I, the nun Kisagotamī, my heart well-freed, say this.
The nun Kajaṅgalikā is astute, she has great wisdom. If you came to me and asked this question, I would answer it in exactly the same way .
The nun Khemā has a good reputation as being astute, competent, clever, learned, a brilliant speaker, and eloquent.
I will not pass away until I have disciples who are competent, educated, and assured among the monks, nun, laymen, and laywomen.
Any monk, nun, layman, or laywoman honors the Buddha by practising the Dhamma properly.
The monks and nuns are like a fertile field for teaching.
A faithful laywoman would rightly aspire: ‘May I be like the laywomen Khujjuttarā and Veḷukaṇṭakī, Nanda’s mother!’
Sāriputta is like the mother who gives birth, while Moggallāna is like the one who raises the child.
A disciplined mind brings happiness.

Irrigators guide water, fletchers shape arrows,
carpenters fashion wood, the virtuous tame themselves.

Do no evil, only do good, and purify the mind:
this is the teaching of the Buddhas.
You’re not wise just because you speak a lot.
Let them not do the slightest thing that the wise would later reprove.
May all beings be happy!

Today’s the day to keenly strive—
who knows, tomorrow may bring death!

What’s past is left behind; the future’s not arrived;
and phenomena in the present are clearly seen in every case.
Be my heirs in spiritual things, not heirs of material things
When my mind was purified, I recollected my many past lives.
I understood: ‘Rebirth is ended; the spiritual journey has been completed; what had to be done has been done; there is no return to any state of existence.’
In the seen there shall be merely the seen.
I am one of those who sleep well in the world.
I shall strive to let go of all attachments.
We will give up the crooks, flaws, and defects of body, speech, and mind.
We will have keen enthusiasm for undertaking the training in the higher ethics, the higher mind, and the higher wisdom.
Nothing is worth clinging on to.
This is peaceful; this is sublime.

Some don’t realize that we all must die.
But clever people who know this settle their quarrels.

As a solid rock isn’t shaken by the wind,
a wise person isn’t affected by praise and blame.

Better than a thousnad useless words
is a single word that brings you peace.

Though a man might conquer a million enemies in battle,
the supreme victor is the one who conquers himself.

You are the ones who must do the work;
the Buddhas only point the way.
The gift of the teaching excells all other gifts.
I do not see a single thing that’s as quick to change as the mind.
It is intention that I call karma. For after making a choice one acts by way of body, speech, and mind.
All is burning.
In the past, as today, all I describe is suffering and the cessation of suffering.
Everything that has a beginning also has an end.
Don’t neglect wisdom, preserve truth, foster generosity, and train only for peace.
The world is unstable and swept away.
The world has no shelter and no savior.
The world is wanting, insatiable, the slave of craving.
It is in this fathom-long body with its perception and mind that I describe the world, its origin, its cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation.

A young monk, striving in the Buddha’s way,
lights up this world like the moon freed from clouds.
